video.title: Pug Template Engine - Full Tutorial for Beginners
video.description:
Pug (formally known as Jade) is an HTML preprocessor implemented in Node.js. It allows you to render HTML with powerful features such as loops, templates, mixins and native JavaScript logic + support.

Learn how to use Pug in this complete course.

🔗For your reference, check this out:
https://pugjs.org/api/getting-started.html

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00) 1. Getting Started | HTML + NodeJS
⌨️ (4:29) 2. The Basics (Doctypes + HTML Tags)
⌨️ (10:32) 3. IDs and Classes
⌨️ (14:23) 4. Attributes (and Advanced Attribute Features)
⌨️ (24:12) 5. Using CSS (Stylesheets)
⌨️ (30:33) 6. For/Each Loop - Iterate over Arrays and Objects
⌨️ (38:15) 7. Conditionals | If/Else Statements
⌨️ (45:25) 8. Case Statement | Switch Statement
⌨️ (50:20) 9. Includes Statement | Including other Pug files
⌨️ (55:37) 10. Mixins | Reusable blocks of code

🎥Tutorial by dcode. Check out the dcode channel for more great tutorials: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCjX0FtIZBBVD3YoCcxnDC4g

🐦dcode on Twitter: @ dcodeyt

--

replies.author: Nicholas Maniccia
replies.text: Most of the time unless you are writing a small site you will use some technology that is like Pug JS to generate HTML for you.  This is so you can make HTML that is "rendered" or dynamically created on the server before a client loads it in the browser.  PHP is a server side language that also does templating and dynamically creates HTML on the server and injects data into it, modern JavaScript frame works like Next JS offer a bunch of tools and bring a front end component way of thinking to the server.  But overall they are solving the same problem of how to give a client(or any user agent) all the content they will need for the first page they request the first time so they don't have to wait(even if it's a small or an unrecognizable amount of time) for a whole bunch of JavaScript to get parsed and run.  A user will most likely need to make subsequent requests to the server or have the JavaScript update the HTML page after the first request, but this approach eases the load on the client by getting them interacting with you web page faster and allows Search Engine Optimization since web crawlers can't see/create or simply ignore content that is triggered by user interactions.  I am using it because I am familiar with JavaScript more than other server side languages like PHP and Python, and it's easy to get up and running and has the perfect amount of features to create a small to medium sized website that Next or Nuxt JS seem to be a little overkill for.  As always use the tool suited for the job and one that you are most comfortable with so you can get it done quickly and accurately.

topLevelComment.author: Dave Lampton
topLevelComment.text: Keep in mind Pug is intended for generating HTML at development time, not at runtime, therefore the examples used in Parts 7, 8 and 10 are a bit misleading. Pug isn't intended to be used on the server (or in the browser) in any kind of runtime Web application context , such as modifying HTML depending on whether a user is logged-in. You may use Pug to generate the HTML that will be used by a Web application, but that's not the same thing. If you were to use Pug to modify HTML source code on your server at runtime, remember you'd be changing the HTML that is served to all users. Pug's conditionals and cases are intended for development-time decisions about how to generate HTML source code. The Express and React integrations are also for development-time use. For runtime Web application decisions, other technologies would be used on the server and/or in the browser.

replies.author: Ali Mahdi
replies.text: If you use the render() method in Express to parse PUG files you can generate server side pages with no danger of impacting other users. In other words, Pug can be used to generate runtime HTML if done the right way. Your point is valid if the code was writing the HTML locally to the server.
